nodes.text: When a person is induced to state or perform something contrary to a private opinion, they will tend to change that private opinion to be consistent with the overt behavior, and the smaller the external reward or threat used to induce the behavior (i.e., the less external justification), the greater this opinion change will be

Experiment manipulated amount of external justification by assigning subjects to three conditions: Control (no induced statement), One Dollar reward for saying the task was enjoyable, and Twenty Dollar reward for saying the task was enjoyable
Subjects (N initial = 71 male introductory psychology students) performed two monotonous tasks to produce a uniformly negative experience before being asked to make the induced statement

Induced statement procedure: experimenter asked consenting subject to tell a waiting confederate that the experiment was enjoyable using a provided script; One Dollar and Twenty Dollar conditions received payment and signed receipts; Control subjects were not asked to make the statement

Private opinions measured by a blind interviewer after the interaction using four questions with numeric rating scales about enjoyment, learning, scientific importance, and desire to participate again; conversations were secretly taped for analysis

Eleven subjects were excluded from analysis for suspicion of the manipulation, admitting they were instructed, refusing payment, or behaving inconsistently with the procedure, leaving 60 subjects analyzed (20 per condition)

Result: Ratings of how enjoyable the tasks were (directly relevant to created dissonance) averaged -0.45 (Control), +1.35 (One Dollar), and -0.05 (Twenty Dollars) on a -5 to +5 scale; One Dollar was significantly higher than Control (p<.02) and higher than Twenty Dollar (p<.03)

Result: Ratings on how much subjects learned (0-10) showed negligible differences across conditions (Control 3.08, One Dollar 2.80, Twenty Dollars 3.15), indicating the effect was specific rather than general

Result: Ratings of scientific importance and desire to participate again showed patterns consistent with dissonance reduction (One Dollar generally higher than others) but with weaker statistical significance

Evidence: Pattern of means supports prediction that smaller external justification (One Dollar) produced greater attitude change toward saying the tasks were enjoyable than larger external justification (Twenty Dollars) or control

Alternative explanation tested: greater mental rehearsal or more persuasive performance by One Dollar subjects could account for attitude change; taped conversations were transcribed and rated blind on five dimensions to assess this

Evidence from taped interaction ratings: independent raters found no greater rehearsal, content, persuasiveness, or overall convincingness in the One Dollar condition; if anything Twenty Dollar was slightly higher, so improvisation differences do not explain the effect
Conclusion: Findings corroborate cognitive dissonance theory derivations that induced counterattitudinal advocacy produces opinion change and that greater external justification reduces that change
Assumption: Subjects' baseline private opinions were negative about the tasks due to the monotonous design, enabling creation of dissonance when they advocated the tasks were enjoyable
Limitation: Use of a paid student subject pool, single gender sample, and laboratory deception may limit generalizability of the magnitude and context of observed attitude change
